sn22.159:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā …pe… bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.159:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn22.159:1.3.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu, yamahaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
sn22.159:1.3.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

sn22.159:2.2.comm: In giving this teaching, the Buddha is, of course, not teaching Ānanda anything new. Rather, he is indicating the manner of meditation he recommends Ānanda focus on in his retreat.

sn22.159:2.4.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn22.159:2.4.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn22.159:2.6.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn22.159:2.6.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn22.159:2.7.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn22.159:2.14.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn22.159:2.14.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn22.159:2.16.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn22.159:2.16.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn22.159:2.17.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn22.159:2.20.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.159:4.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on the aggregates are complete.

sn22.16:1.4.pli: yadanattā taṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.16:1.4.eng: And what’s not-self should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.16:1.10.pli: yadanattā taṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.16:1.10.eng: And what’s not-self should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.16:1.12.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.17:1.3.pli: Yadanattā taṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.17:1.3.eng: And what’s not-self should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.17:1.8.pli: Yadanattā taṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.17:1.8.eng: And what’s not-self should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.17:1.10.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.18:1.3.pli: Yopi hetu, yopi paccayo rūpassa uppādāya, sopi anicco.
sn22.18:1.3.eng: The cause and reason that gives rise to form is also impermanent.

sn22.18:1.4.pli: Aniccasambhūtaṃ, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ kuto niccaṃ bhavissati.
sn22.18:1.4.eng: Since form is produced by what is impermanent, how could it be permanent?

sn22.18:1.6.pli: Yopi hetu, yopi paccayo vedanāya uppādāya, sopi anicco.

sn22.18:1.7.pli: Aniccasambhūtā, bhikkhave, vedanā kuto niccā bhavissati.

sn22.18:1.10.pli: Yopi hetu yopi paccayo saṅkhārānaṃ uppādāya, sopi anicco.

sn22.18:1.11.pli: Aniccasambhūtā, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā kuto niccā bhavissanti.

sn22.18:1.13.pli: Yopi hetu yopi paccayo viññāṇassa uppādāya, sopi anicco.
sn22.18:1.13.eng: The cause and reason that gives rise to consciousness is also impermanent.

sn22.18:1.14.pli: Aniccasambhūtaṃ, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṃ kuto niccaṃ bhavissati.
sn22.18:1.14.eng: Since consciousness is produced by what is impermanent, how could it be permanent?

sn22.18:1.16.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.19:1.3.pli: Yopi hetu yopi paccayo rūpassa uppādāya, sopi dukkho.
sn22.19:1.3.eng: The cause and reason that gives rise to form is also suffering.

sn22.19:1.4.pli: Dukkhasambhūtaṃ, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ kuto sukhaṃ bhavissati.
sn22.19:1.4.eng: Since form is produced by what is suffering, how could it be happiness?

sn22.19:1.9.pli: Yopi hetu yopi paccayo viññāṇassa uppādāya, sopi dukkho.
sn22.19:1.9.eng: The cause and reason that gives rise to consciousness is also suffering.

sn22.19:1.10.pli: Dukkhasambhūtaṃ, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṃ kuto sukhaṃ bhavissati.
sn22.19:1.10.eng: Since consciousness is produced by what is suffering, how could it be happiness?

sn22.19:1.12.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.2:1.1.comm: This discourse contains Sāriputta’s advice for Buddhists teaching Dhamma in a strange land. He shows a method of giving a small amount of knowledge at a time, enough to digest and to stimulate further questioning. Indeed, he takes it for granted that the process is led by the student’s curiosity, rather than by missionary zeal for conversion.

sn22.2:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati devadahaṃ nāma sakyānaṃ nigamo.
sn22.2:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, where they have a town named Devadaha.
sn22.2:1.2.comm: Devadaha also appears in MN 101 and SN 35.134. The name is explained in the commentary as “royal lake”, taking deva- as a term for kings, and -daha as equivalent to the Sanskrit hrada, “lake”. However it is spelled devadṛśa in the Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya (San Mu Kd 17:16). Dṛśa means “sight, appearance”, thus occupying a completely different semantic space than “lake”. It is a Vedic term that commonly describes Agni’s fiery gleam (Rig Veda 3.17.4, 6.10.4, 7.1.1, etc.). This suggests a Pali derivation from √ḍah, “to burn”. This in turn recalls Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.4.1.14, which allegorically depicts the spread of Aryan culture eastward as Agni “burning” (dadāha) the lands, i.e. introducing the civilized practice of Vedic fire worship. I think the meaning of devadaha is, therefore, “burned by the god”, or “place of the god’s flame”. It became famous in later Buddhism as the birthplace of the sisters Māyā and Mahāpajāpatī of the Koliyan clan, the Buddha’s birth mother and foster mother. These details are not mentioned in early texts, however, where the town is said to be Sakyan rather than Koliyan. It is identified with Devdaha in the Rupandehi District of Nepal.

sn22.2:1.3.pli: Atha kho sambahulā pacchābhūmagamikā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn22.2:1.3.eng: Then several mendicants who were heading for the west went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

sn22.2:1.4.pli: “icchāma mayaṃ, bhante, pacchābhūmaṃ janapadaṃ gantuṃ, pacchābhūme janapade nivāsaṃ kappetun”ti.
sn22.2:1.4.eng: “Sir, we wish to go to a western land to take up residence there.”
sn22.2:1.4.comm: The “western land” (pacchābhūma) is not identified, but presumably lay to the west of Verañjā (MN 42:2.1) or Kuru. See SN 42.6:2.1 and note for the “brahmins of the western land”.

sn22.2:2.1.eng: “But mendicants, have you taken leave of Sāriputta?”

sn22.2:2.2.pli: “Na kho no, bhante, apalokito āyasmā sāriputto”ti.

sn22.2:2.4.pli: Sāriputto, bhikkhave, paṇḍito, bhikkhūnaṃ anuggāhako sabrahmacārīnan”ti.
sn22.2:2.4.eng: He’s astute, and supports his spiritual companions, the mendicants.”

sn22.2:2.5.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

sn22.2:3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā sāriputto bhagavato avidūre aññatarasmiṃ eḷagalāgumbe nisinno hoti.
sn22.2:3.1.eng: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was sitting not far from the Buddha in a clump of golden shower trees.
sn22.2:3.1.comm: Eḷagalā is sometimes identified with cassia tora, but that is an introduced shrub. Perhaps it is cassia fistula (Sanskrit āragvadha), a smallish tree, native to India, with a glorious crown of golden flowers. It is the national tree of Thailand and frequently adorns temples in Sri Lanka.

sn22.2:3.2.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu.
sn22.2:3.2.eng: And then those mendicants approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. They got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right. Then they went up to Venerable Sāriputta, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn22.2:3.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn22.2:3.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side and said to him,

sn22.2:3.4.pli: “icchāma mayaṃ, āvuso sāriputta, pacchābhūmaṃ janapadaṃ gantuṃ, pacchābhūme janapade nivāsaṃ kappetuṃ.
sn22.2:3.4.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, we wish to go to a western land to take up residence there.

sn22.2:3.5.eng: We have taken leave of the Teacher.”

sn22.2:4.1.eng: “Reverends, there are those who question a mendicant who has gone abroad—
sn22.2:4.1.comm: “Abroad” is nānāverajja, “dominion of a different king”.

sn22.2:4.2.eng: astute aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and ascetics—

sn22.2:4.4.pli: ‘kiṃvādī panāyasmantānaṃ satthā kimakkhāyī’ti, kacci vo āyasmantānaṃ dhammā sussutā suggahitā sumanasikatā sūpadhāritā suppaṭividdhā paññāya, yathā byākaramānā āyasmanto vuttavādino ceva bhagavato assatha, na ca bhagavantaṃ abhūtena abbhācikkheyyātha, dhammassa cānudhammaṃ byākareyyātha, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānuvādo gārayhaṃ ṭhānaṃ āgaccheyyā”ti?
sn22.2:4.4.eng: ‘But what does the venerables’ Teacher teach? What does he explain?’ I trust the venerables have properly heard, learned, applied the mind, and remembered the teachings, and penetrated them with wisdom. That way, when answering you will repeat what the Buddha has said and not misrepresent him with an untruth. You will explain in line with the teaching, with no legitimate grounds for rebuttal and criticism.”

sn22.2:5.1.pli: “Dūratopi kho mayaṃ, āvuso, āgaccheyyāma āyasmato sāriputtassa santike etassa bhāsitassa atthamaññātuṃ.
sn22.2:5.1.eng: “Reverend, we would travel a long way to learn the meaning of this statement in the presence of Venerable Sāriputta.

sn22.2:5.2.pli: Sādhu vatāyasmantaṃyeva sāriputtaṃ paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho”ti.
sn22.2:5.2.eng: May Venerable Sāriputta himself please clarify the meaning of this.”

sn22.2:5.3.pli: “Tena hāvuso, suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
sn22.2:5.3.eng: “Well then, reverends, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn22.2:5.4.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosuṃ.

sn22.2:6.1.eng: “Reverends, there are those who question a mendicant who has gone abroad—

sn22.2:6.2.eng: astute aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and ascetics—

sn22.2:6.4.eng: ‘But what does the venerables’ Teacher teach? What does he explain?’

sn22.2:6.5.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, āvuso, evaṃ byākareyyātha:
sn22.2:6.5.eng: When questioned like this, reverends, you should answer:

sn22.2:6.6.eng: ‘Reverend, our Teacher explained the removal of desire and lust.’

sn22.2:7.1.pli: Evaṃ byākatepi kho, āvuso, assuyeva uttariṃ pañhaṃ pucchitāro—
sn22.2:7.1.eng: When you answer like this, such astute people may inquire further:

sn22.2:7.4.eng: ‘But regarding what does the venerables’ teacher explain the removal of desire and lust?’

sn22.2:7.5.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, āvuso, evaṃ byākareyyātha:
sn22.2:7.5.eng: When questioned like this, reverends, you should answer:

sn22.2:7.6.eng: ‘Our teacher explains the removal of desire and lust for form,
sn22.2:7.6.comm: The aggregates are presented under the assumption that someone knowing nothing about Buddhism would understand them.

sn22.2:7.8.comm: Sanskrit saṁjñā came to be used in a wide variety of senses, but the pre-Buddhist usage is quite restricted. The basic meaning is “agreement, concord, mutual understanding” (Rig Veda 10.19.4, Atharva Veda 7.52.1, Śathapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.1.4.5), from which we have the causative sense in Pali, “persuade, reach an agreement with” (DN 29:18.8, Ud 2.8:13.1, Bu NP 10:1.1.14). This becomes an unsettling euphemism in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, where the sacrificial beast is “persuaded” or “made to consent”, for “when they make the victim consent, they kill it” (ŚB 13.2.8.2). There seems no real precedent for the Buddhist sense of “perception” until Yājñavalkya at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.12 and 4.5.13, to which DN 9 appears as a direct response. That passage contrasts the “limited” knowing of saṁjñā with the “infinite” knowing of vijñāna. Vijñāna likewise has little precedent; previously, it just meant knowing or understanding. Most likely both terms were established as an artificial pair by Yājñavalkya due to their contrasting prefixes. This led to the Buddhist idea of “perception” as a limited, conventional mode of knowing or recognizing, a usage also found in the Jain Tattvārthasūtra 1.13.

sn22.2:8.1.pli: Evaṃ byākatepi kho, āvuso, assuyeva uttariṃ pañhaṃ pucchitāro—
sn22.2:8.1.eng: When you answer like this, such astute people may inquire further:

sn22.2:8.4.pli: ‘kiṃ panāyasmantānaṃ ādīnavaṃ disvā rūpe chandarāgavinayakkhāyī satthā,
sn22.2:8.4.eng: ‘But what drawback has he seen that he teaches the removal of desire and lust for form,

sn22.2:8.9.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, āvuso, evaṃ byākareyyātha:
sn22.2:8.9.eng: When questioned like this, reverends, you should answer:

sn22.2:8.10.pli: ‘rūpe kho, āvuso, avigatarāgassa avigatacchandassa avigatapemassa avigatapipāsassa avigatapariḷāhassa avigatataṇhassa tassa rūpassa vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā.
sn22.2:8.10.eng: ‘If you’re not free of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for form, when that form decays and perishes it gives rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn22.2:8.11.eng: If you’re not free of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for feeling …

sn22.2:8.14.pli: avigatataṇhassa tesaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā.

sn22.2:8.15.pli: Viññāṇe avigatarāgassa avigatacchandassa avigatapemassa avigatapipāsassa avigatapariḷāhassa avigatataṇhassa tassa viññāṇassa vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā.
sn22.2:8.15.eng: consciousness, when that consciousness decays and perishes it gives rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn22.2:8.16.pli: Idaṃ kho no, āvuso, ādīnavaṃ disvā rūpe chandarāgavinayakkhāyī satthā,
sn22.2:8.16.eng: This is the drawback our Teacher has seen that he teaches the removal of desire and lust for form,

sn22.2:9.1.pli: Evaṃ byākatepi kho, āvuso, assuyeva uttariṃ pañhaṃ pucchitāro—
sn22.2:9.1.eng: When you answer like this, such astute people may inquire further:

sn22.2:9.4.pli: ‘kiṃ panāyasmantānaṃ ānisaṃsaṃ disvā rūpe chandarāgavinayakkhāyī satthā,
sn22.2:9.4.eng: ‘But what benefit has he seen that he teaches the removal of desire and lust for form,

sn22.2:9.9.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, āvuso, evaṃ byākareyyātha:
sn22.2:9.9.eng: When questioned like this, reverends, you should answer:

sn22.2:9.10.pli: ‘rūpe kho, āvuso, vigatarāgassa vigatacchandassa vigatapemassa vigatapipāsassa vigatapariḷāhassa vigatataṇhassa tassa rūpassa vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā nuppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā.
sn22.2:9.10.eng: ‘If you are rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for form, when that form decays and perishes it doesn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn22.2:9.11.eng: If you are rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for feeling …

sn22.2:9.13.pli: saṅkhāresu vigatarāgassa vigatacchandassa vigatapemassa vigatapipāsassa vigatapariḷāhassa vigatataṇhassa tesaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā nuppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā.

sn22.2:9.14.pli: Viññāṇe vigatarāgassa vigatacchandassa vigatapemassa vigatapipāsassa vigatapariḷāhassa vigatataṇhassa tassa viññāṇassa vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā nuppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā.
sn22.2:9.14.eng: consciousness, when that consciousness decays and perishes it doesn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn22.2:9.15.pli: Idaṃ kho no, āvuso, ānisaṃsaṃ disvā rūpe chandarāgavinayakkhāyī satthā, vedanāya …
sn22.2:9.15.eng: This is the benefit our Teacher has seen that he teaches the removal of desire and lust for form, feeling,

sn22.2:10.1.pli: Akusale cāvuso, dhamme upasampajja viharato diṭṭhe ceva dhamme sukho vihāro abhavissa avighāto anupāyāso apariḷāho, kāyassa ca bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugati pāṭikaṅkhā, nayidaṃ bhagavā akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānaṃ vaṇṇeyya.
sn22.2:10.1.eng: If those who acquired and kept unskillful qualities were to live happily in the present life, free of distress, anguish, and fever; and if, when their body breaks up, after death, they could expect to go to a good place, the Buddha would not praise giving up unskillful qualities.
sn22.2:10.1.comm: Good and evil are consequential, not absolute.

sn22.2:10.2.pli: Yasmā ca kho, āvuso, akusale dhamme upasampajja viharato diṭṭhe ceva dhamme dukkho vihāro savighāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho, kāyassa ca bhedā paraṃ maraṇā duggati pāṭikaṅkhā, tasmā bhagavā akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānaṃ vaṇṇeti.
sn22.2:10.2.eng: But since those who acquire and keep unskillful qualities live unhappily in the present life, full of distress, anguish, and fever; and since, when their body breaks up, after death, they can expect to go to a bad place, the Buddha praises giving up unskillful qualities.

sn22.2:11.1.pli: Kusale cāvuso, dhamme upasampajja viharato diṭṭhe ceva dhamme dukkho vihāro abhavissa savighāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho, kāyassa ca bhedā paraṃ maraṇā duggati pāṭikaṅkhā, nayidaṃ bhagavā kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadaṃ vaṇṇeyya.
sn22.2:11.1.eng: If those who embraced and kept skillful qualities were to live unhappily in the present life, full of distress, anguish, and fever; and if, when their body breaks up, after death, they could expect to go to a bad place, the Buddha would not praise embracing skillful qualities.

sn22.2:11.2.pli: Yasmā ca kho, āvuso, kusale dhamme upasampajja viharato diṭṭhe ceva dhamme sukho vihāro avighāto anupāyāso apariḷāho, kāyassa ca bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugati pāṭikaṅkhā, tasmā bhagavā kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadaṃ vaṇṇetī”ti.
sn22.2:11.2.eng: But since those who embrace and keep skillful qualities live happily in the present life, free of distress, anguish, and fever; and since, when their body breaks up, after death, they can expect to go to a good place, the Buddha praises embracing skillful qualities.”

sn22.2:12.1.eng: This is what Venerable Sāriputta said.

sn22.2:12.2.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
sn22.2:12.2.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what Sāriputta said.

sn22.20:1.3.pli: Yopi hetu yopi paccayo rūpassa uppādāya, sopi anattā.
sn22.20:1.3.eng: The cause and reason that gives rise to form is also not-self.

sn22.20:1.4.pli: Anattasambhūtaṃ, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ kuto attā bhavissati.
sn22.20:1.4.eng: Since form is produced by what is not-self, how could it be self?

sn22.20:1.9.pli: Yopi hetu yopi paccayo viññāṇassa uppādāya, sopi anattā.
sn22.20:1.9.eng: The cause and reason that gives rise to consciousness is also not-self.

sn22.20:1.10.pli: Anattasambhūtaṃ, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṃ kuto attā bhavissati.
sn22.20:1.10.eng: Since consciousness is produced by what is not-self, how could it be self?

sn22.20:1.12.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.21:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.21:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha:

sn22.21:1.4.pli: Katamesānaṃ kho, bhante, dhammānaṃ nirodho ‘nirodho’ti vuccatī”ti?
sn22.21:1.4.eng: The cessation of what things does this refer to?”

sn22.21:1.5.pli: “Rūpaṃ kho, ānanda, aniccaṃ saṅkhataṃ paṭiccasamuppannaṃ khayadhammaṃ vayadhammaṃ virāgadhammaṃ nirodhadhammaṃ.
sn22.21:1.5.eng: “Ānanda, form is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, liable to end, vanish, fade away, and cease.

sn22.21:1.6.eng: Its cessation is what ‘cessation’ refers to.

sn22.21:1.7.pli: Vedanā aniccā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā khayadhammā vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammā.

sn22.21:1.10.pli: saṅkhārā aniccā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā khayadhammā vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammā.

sn22.21:1.12.pli: Viññāṇaṃ aniccaṃ saṅkhataṃ paṭiccasamuppannaṃ khayadhammaṃ vayadhammaṃ virāgadhammaṃ nirodhadhammaṃ.
sn22.21:1.12.eng: Consciousness is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, liable to end, vanish, fade away, and cease.

sn22.21:1.13.eng: Its cessation is what ‘cessation’ refers to.

sn22.21:1.14.pli: Imesaṃ kho, ānanda, dhammānaṃ nirodho ‘nirodho’ti vuccatī”ti.
sn22.21:1.14.eng: When they speak of ‘cessation’, its the cessation of these things that this refers to.”
